moduleGroup.name: Registration Using AIR
moduleGroup.description: This is a simple registration workflow. The structural MRI images are aligned to a standard brain image by using AIR registration tools. To build this workflow follow the steps mentioned on the following pages.

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165.PMID: 9448780

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152.PMID: 9448779

module.name: Reslice
module.description:
An AIR linear transformation is applied to a Volume to bring it from the compatible source space to the target space specified within the transform.
64-bit compilation 16-bit output

input.name: Input (.air Linear Transformation)
input.description: Defines the source space and the target space for the source volume to transformed into. The source space and the source volume must possess compatible dimensions and should be of the same space.

output.name: Output (Resliced Volume)
output.description: A new volume created by the application of the given transform to the given volume in the target space provided by the transform.

input.name: Alternate Reslice File
input.description: A volume compatible with the source space in the transform file that is to be converted to the target space provided by the transform.

input.name: Divide by Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: Change the output intensities of the produced volume by dividing by this scale factor.

input.name: Divide by Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: scales output by dividing by factor specified in the ASCII file. The file must contain a single positive number

input.name: Retain Standard Volume's Voxel Dimensions
input.description: Does not allow cubic interpolation of voxels in the target space, but instead retains the voxel dimensions of the standard file that defines the target space.

input.name: Interpolation Model 2,3,4
input.description:
The type of interpolation to be used to create the new volume:
2: Windowed sinc in the original XY plane, linear along Z. (requires the X- and Y-half-window-widths be provided). 3: Windowed sinc in the original XZ plane, linear along Y. (requires the X- and Z-half-window-widths be provided). 4: Windowed sinc in the original YZ plane, linear along X. (requires the Y- and Z-half-window-widths be provided).

input.name: Overwrite
input.description: grants permission to overwrite output

input.name: Multiply by Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: Change the output intensities of the produced volume by mutiplying by this scale factor.

input.name: Multiplicative Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: output intensities are multiplied by the value in this ASCII file containing a single positive number

input.name: Alternate X-dimension/size/shift
input.description:
the shift (in voxels) to be applied along the X dimension, with positive and negative values causing shifts in opposite directions
OR
the new desired voxel size along the X dimension (in whatever unit was used for sizes in your image files, usually millimeters)

input.name: Alternate Y-dimension/size/shift
input.description:
the shift (in voxels) to be applied along the Y dimension, with positive and negative values causing shifts in opposite directions
OR
the new desired voxel size along the Y dimension (in whatever unit was used for sizes in your image files, usually millimeters)

input.name: Alternate Z-dimension/size/shift
input.description:
the shift (in voxels) to be applied along the Z dimension, with positive and negative values causing shifts in opposite directions
OR
the new desired voxel size along the Z dimension (in whatever unit was used for sizes in your image files, usually millimeters)

input.name: Interpolation Model 0, 1, 7, 10-13
input.description:
The type of interpolation to be used to create the new volume:
0: Nearest neighbor (should be used for enumerated value files where only specific values have meanings and should be available). 1: Trilinear 7: 3D unwindowed scanline sinc. 10: 3D scanline chirp-z. 11: scanline chirp-z in the original XY plane, linear along the Z-axis. 12: scanline chirp-z in the original XZ plane, linear along the Y-axis. 13: scanline chirp-z in the original YZ plane, linear along the X-axis.

input.name: Interpolation Model 5,6
input.description:
The type of interpolation to be used to create the new volume:
5: 3D windowed sinc. (requires the X-, Y-, and Z-half-window-widths be provided). 6: 3D windowed scanline sinc. (requires the X-, Y-, and Z-half-window-widths be provided).

module.name: Align Linear
module.description:
This is a general linear intramodality registration tool (within or across subjects, 2D or 3D). The user can specify any of a variety of models, including rigid-body, affine, or perspective.
The program will generate a .air file that can be used to reslice the specified reslice data set to match the specified standard data set.
64-bit compilation

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152.PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165.PMID: 9448780

input.name: Standard Volume
input.description: The atlas that the input file is resliced to match.

input.name: Reslice Volume
input.description: The input being registered to the standard-file.

output.name: Linear Transformation
output.description: Resultant linear spatial transformation matrix saved as a .air file

input.name: Model Number
input.description: Defines the degrees of freedom of the transformation. 3-D models: 6. rigid body 6 parameter model 7. global rescale 7 parameter model 9. traditional 9 parameter model (std must be on AC-PC line) 12. affine 12 parameter model 15. perspective 15 parameter model 2-D models (constrained to in-plane, no interpolation): 23. 2-D rigid body 3 parameter model 24. 2-D global rescale 4 parameter model 25. 2-D affine/fixed determinant 5 parameter model 26. 2-D affine 6 parameter model 28. 2-D perspective 8 parameter model AIR 5.0

input.name: Threshold Standard
input.description: The threshold for the Standard Volume defines a minimum voxel value. Voxels in the Standard Volume with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Threshold Reslice
input.description: The threshold for the Reslice Volume defines a minimum voxel value. Voxels in the Reslice Volume with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Blur Standard
input.description: The Gaussian smoothing filter for the Standard Volume. Smoothing filters are applied along the x, y, and z axes of the Standard Volume before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Blur Reslice
input.description: The Gaussian smoothing filter for the Reslice Volume. Smoothing filters are applied along the x, y, and z axes of the Reslice Volume before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Segment Standard
input.description:
Number of partitions for the standard image. This defines the number of partitions used for segmenting the standard file in the forward direction WHEN USING THE STANDARD DEVIATION OF THE RATIO IMAGE AS THE COST FUNCITON. If this value is zero, no forward direction computation is performed. A value of 256 is typically used for intermodality registration when the corresponding file is an MRI study. For MRI-PET registration, the number of partitions corresponding to the PET study should be set to zero. When registering two dissimilar MR images, both data sets can be assigned 256 partitions. For intramodality registration, the default value of 1 is appropriate.
AIR 5.0 Note that AIR now uses dynamic partitioning by default. Instead of dividing the theoretical range of voxel intensities into the designated number of partitions, the actual range of voxel intensities is divided into this number of partitions. This assures that when the dynamic range of the data is restricted, the voxels do not all end up occupying far fewer partitions than requested. The "Static Partitioning" option forces the use of static partitioning as in AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Segment Reslice
input.description:
Number of partitions for the Reslice Volume. This defines the number of partitions used for segmenting the Reslice Volume in the reverse direction WHEN USING THE STANDARD DEVIATION OF THE RATIO IMAGE AS THE COST FUNCITON. If this value is zero, no reverse direction computation is performed. A value of 256 is typically used for intermodality registration when the corresponding file is an MRI study. For MRI-PET registration, the number of partitions corresponding to the PET study should be set to zero. When registering two dissimilar MR images, both data sets can be assigned 256 partitions. For intramodality registration, the default value of 1 is appropriate.
AIR 5.0 Note that AIR now uses dynamic partitioning by default. Instead of dividing the theoretical range of voxel intensities into the designated number of partitions, the actual range of voxel intensities is divided into this number of partitions. This assures that when the dynamic range of the data is restricted, the voxels do not all end up occupying far fewer partitions than requested. The "Static Partitioning" option forces the use of static partitioning as in AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Standard Mask Volume
input.description: This volume is applied to the Standard Volume as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Reslice Mask Volume
input.description: This volume is applied to the Reslice Volume as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Spatial Initialization
input.description: An ASCII file containing spatial transformation initialization parameters. These parameters can be used to control the starting position for automated registration, a feature that is useful if the initial misregistration is extreme (e.g., > 45 degrees of rotational misregistration) or if the default registration leads to an obviously incorrect result. Different spatial models require different numbers and types of parameters in the initialization file. Note that some cost functions may also allow an intensity parameter initialization file as well.

output.name: Spatial Termination
output.description: An ASCII file to be created containing spatial transformation termination parameters. These parameters can then be used as initialization parameters to restart the algorithm at the same location in parameter space where it left off (using the same spatial model). This allows you to switch cost functions or to vary smoothing, among other things. Different spatial models create incompatible files. Note that some cost functions may also allow an intensity parameter termination file.

input.name: Scaling Initialization
input.description: An ASCII file containing a single parameter that initializes intensity scaling.

output.name: Scaling Termination
output.description:
An ASCII file containing the intensity scaling parameter identified as optimal by the algorithm. Combined with a spatial transformation initialization file, this parameter can be used to restart the algorithm at the same location in parameter space where it left off. In addition, the scaling parameter can be used as an intensity normalization factor for subsequent statistical analysis of the registered data or as input to reslice to create a final image that is intensity corrected as well as spatially corrrected.
NOTE: The cost function needs to be set to 3 for this to work

input.name: Samplings
input.description: Determines the number of intermediate iterative cycles of the algorithm. The current sampling is divided by this ratio with each cycle to determine the new sampling.

input.name: Convergence Threshold
input.description: Controls how small the predicted change in the cost function must be in order to meet the convergence criteria. Setting this value too large will result in convergence while the images are still misregistered; setting it too small may lead to a failure to converge.

input.name: Repeated Iterations
input.description: The maximum number of iterations permitted at each sampling density. If this number is made too low, it will lead to inaccurate results and/or slow down the overall performance of the algorithm by preventing you from making use of information that could have been derived more quickly at the prematurely aborted, more superficial sampling.

input.name: Halt After Steps Without Improvement
input.description: The maximum number of iterations without any observed improvement in the cost function. If greater than or equal to repeated-iterations, this value has no effect. At lower values, it can help you escape from situations where you are bouncing back and forth between two or three locations in parameter space without making any real progress. This sort of thing usually only happens at superficial sampling densities.

input.name: Use Non-positive Definite Hessian Matrices
input.description: A currently unvalidated method for overcoming non-positive definite Hessian matrices.

input.name: Static Partitioning (AIR 3.0 compatible)
input.description: Forces the use of static partitioning, reverting to the default behavior of AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Non-interaction of Spatial Parameter Derivatives
input.description: Assumes a non-interaction of spatial parameter derivatives (reduces likelihood of non-positive definite Hessian matrices).

input.name: Verbose
input.description: Extremely detailed reporting of interim results.

input.name: Pre-alignment Interpolation
input.description: Provides pre-alignment interpolation to cubic voxels.

input.name: Cost Function
input.description:
The cost function to be used for alignemtn as selected from the following menu: 1. Standard deviation of ratio images cost function: This cost function has the advantage of being independent of image intensity, so image intensities can be poorly matched and the registration will not be adversely affected. This is the only model that allows multiple partitions as required for intermodality registration.
2. Least squares cost function: This cost function assumes that the image intensities are scaled identically. Least squares is computationally simpler and therefore faster than the standard deviation of ratio images, but may be inaccurate if the image intensities are poorly matched.
3. Least squares with global rescaling cost function This cost function is identical to the least squares cost function except that an intensity scaling term is added to the model.

viewerModule.name: LONI Viewer
viewerModule.description:
This is a general, versatile and light-weight viewer, which allows visualzaition of:
1. Volumetric data parseable by the LONI Debabeler (http://www.loni.ucla.edu/Software/Debabeler)
2. Shape/Surface objects in any of the ShapeTools geometry shape formats (http://www.loni.ucla.edu/Software/ShapeTools).

filetype.name: MESH obj
filetype.description: A type of MESH obj file.

annotation.name: Run four instances of AIR's linear alignment tool, registering the reslice volume to the standard using translations with 6, 7, 9, and 12 degrees of freedom.

style.name: Run four instances of AIR's linear alignment tool, registering the reslice volume to the standard using translations with 6, 7, 9, and 12 degrees of freedom.$0

annotation.name: Reslice takes the .air file generated by Align Linear and applies the transformation to the reslice volume, completing the registration process

style.name: Reslice takes the .air file generated by Align Linear and applies the transformation to the reslice volume, completing the registration process$0

annotation.name: Output the registered image to the Data Source, where a destination path is provided for file storage.

style.name: Output the registered image to the Data Source, where a destination path is provided for file storage.$0
